title: Restoration of Benjamin
shortSummary: Judges 21 recounts the aftermath of the civil war against the tribe of Benjamin, focusing on Israel’s efforts to provide wives for the surviving Benjamites without breaking their oath. The chapter highlights Israel’s repentance, creative yet flawed solutions to preserve the tribe, and the chaotic state of the nation without a king.
timeline: c. 1375 BC - Period of the Judges, after the civil conflict involving Benjamin

keyCharacters.name: Men of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The collective tribes of Israel who made a solemn oath not to give their daughters to Benjamin and later sought to remedy the consequences of that oath.

keyCharacters.name: Benjamin
keyCharacters.description: The tribe nearly wiped out in the civil war, struggling to find wives to preserve their lineage.

keyCharacters.name: Elders of the Congregation
keyCharacters.description: Leaders who guided Israel in decision-making after the war, seeking solutions to maintain the tribe of Benjamin.

definitions.definition: A gathering place in Israel where the people assembled to make solemn vows and seek God’s guidance.
A solemn promise made before God, binding the Israelites not to give their daughters as wives to Benjamin.
A town whose inhabitants failed to join the assembly at Mizpeh and were subsequently punished by Israel.
Sacrificial offerings made to God expressing fellowship, gratitude, and reconciliation.

outline.heading: Israel’s Oath and Repentance
outline.description: Israel had sworn not to give their daughters to Benjamin, but after realizing the tribe was nearly destroyed, they repented and sought a way to provide wives for the remaining Benjamites, highlighting the tension between vows and mercy.

outline.heading: Punishment of Jabeshgilead and Provision of Wives
outline.description: Israel identified Jabeshgilead as the town that did not join the assembly and destroyed its inhabitants except for 400 virgins, who were given as wives to Benjamin, demonstrating a harsh but practical solution to preserve the tribe.

outline.heading: The Festival at Shiloh and Additional Wives
outline.description: Because the wives from Jabeshgilead were insufficient, Israel instructed Benjamin to abduct wives during a festival at Shiloh, showing the lengths Israel went to maintain tribal continuity despite their oath.

outline.heading: Conclusion: Israel’s Disorder
outline.description: The chapter closes by noting that Israel returned to their homes, but without a king, each did what was right in his own eyes, underscoring the moral and social chaos of the period.

application: Recognize the importance of seeking God’s guidance when making vows and the need for repentance when we fail to uphold God’s purposes.
Trust God’s providence even in difficult circumstances, as He can work through imperfect human decisions to preserve His people.
Avoid making rash promises that may lead to unintended consequences; instead, commit to obedience and faithfulness to God’s Word.
Understand the dangers of moral relativism and the need for godly leadership to guide the community in righteousness.

keyVerses.text: And the children of Israel repented them for Benjamin their brother, and said, There is one tribe cut off from Israel this day.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures Israel’s sorrow and repentance over the near destruction of one of their tribes, emphasizing the value of every part of God’s people.

keyVerses.text: In those days there was no king in Israel: every man did that which was right in his own eyes.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the root cause of Israel’s chaos and moral decline during the period of the Judges, underscoring the need for godly leadership.

keyVerses.text: And Benjamin came again at that time; and they gave them wives which they had saved alive of the women of Jabeshgilead: and yet so they sufficed them not.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the partial solution to Benjamin’s crisis and sets the stage for further actions, illustrating the complexity of balancing vows with mercy.
